title.value: Deep Networks as Paths on the Manifold of Neural Representations
title.justification: The exact title as stated in the paper.
title.quote: Deep Networks as Paths on the Manifold of Neural Representations

extractions.description: This paper explores a novel perspective on deep neural networks by conceptualizing them as traversing paths on a high-dimensional manifold of neural representations. It leverages advanced representational similarity metrics to analyze and visualize these paths, thereby offering new insights into the layer-wise transformations and overall geometry of neural network computations.

type.justification: The paper primarily presents a theoretical framework for understanding deep neural networks through geometric and mathematical concepts.
type.quote: We formalize this intuitive idea by leveraging recent advances in metric representational similarity.

name.justification: The research is centered around understanding and conceptualizing the behavior of deep neural networks.
name.quote: Deep neural networks implement a sequence of layer-by-layer operations that are each relatively easy to understand, but the resulting overall computation is generally difficult to understand.

name.justification: The focus is on analyzing how neural representations evolve through the layers of a network.
name.quote: We imagine that outputs are 'far' from inputs if the mapping between them is complex, or 'close' if it is simple. In this spatial analogy, one layer of a neural network contributes a single step, and the composition of many steps transports representations along a path towards the desired target representation.

name.justification: The paper uses geometrical concepts like manifolds, geodesics, and tangent spaces to analyze neural networks.
name.quote: Embedding hidden-layers on a smooth manifold endows every operation in the network with a sense of both distance and direction.

name.justification: The paper uses ResNet models to illustrate its concepts and findings.
name.quote: Schematic of model architecture with color-coded layers. Gray boxes correspond to residual blocks.

is_contributed.justification: ResNet is not a new model introduced by this paper; it is used as a tool for experiments.
is_contributed.quote: We then demonstrate these tools by visualizing and comparing the paths taken by a collection of trained neural networks with a variety of architectures.

is_executed.justification: The ResNet models are executed to visualize and compare paths on the manifold.
is_executed.quote: We visualize and compare the paths taken by a collection of trained neural networks with a variety of architectures.

is_compared.justification: ResNet models are compared with other architectures in terms of their paths on the manifold.
is_compared.quote: We compare paths taken by different models, different datasets, and changes over training.

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition
referenced_paper_title.quote: He, K., Zhang, X., Ren, S., and Sun, J. Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition. CVPR, 2016.

name.justification: VGG models are used alongside ResNet models for experiments.
name.quote: We trained a variety of standard 'wide' and 'deep' ResNet models (He et al., 2016; Nguyen et al., 2021), as well as models from the VGG family (Simonyan & Zisserman, 2015), on the CIFAR-10 dataset.

is_contributed.justification: The VGG model is not a new model introduced by this paper; it is used for comparison purposes.
is_contributed.quote: We compare paths taken by different models, different datasets, and changes over training.

is_executed.justification: The paper involves executing VGG models to visualize and compare paths on the manifold.
is_executed.quote: We visualize and compare the paths taken by a collection of trained neural networks with a variety of architectures.

is_compared.justification: VGG models are compared with ResNet models and possibly others in terms of their paths on the manifold.
is_compared.quote: We compare paths taken by different models, different datasets, and changes over training.
